column1: '''A Walking Song''' was a song [[Frodo Baggins|Frodo]]
column3: and [[Samwise Gamgee|Sam]] sang as they hiked through the [[Woody End]] on [[24 September]] {{TA|3018}}.<ref>{{App|Great}}</ref>  [[Bilbo Baggins]] had written the words to this song and he put it to a tune that was "as old as the hills."<ref>{{FR|I3}}</ref>  On [[22 September]] {{TA|3021}}<ref>{{App|Later}}</ref> Frodo sang part of an altered version of the song as he was leaving for the [[Undying Lands]].<ref>{{RK|VI9}}</ref>

column1: == Text ==
<poem style="font-style:italic; margin-left:20px;">
Upon the hearth the fire is red
Beneath the roof there is a bed;
But not yet weary are our feet
Still round the corner we may meet
A sudden tree or standing stone
That none have seen but we alone.
Tree and flower and leaf and grass
Let them pass! Let them pass!
Hill and water under sky
Pass them by! Pass them by!
Still round the corner there may wait
A new road or a secret gate
And though we pass them by today
Tomorrow we may come this way
And take the hidden paths that run
Towards the Moon or to the Sun.
Apple
Let them go! Let them go!
Sand and stone and pool and dell
Fare you well! Fare you well!
Home is behind
And there are many paths to tread
Through shadows to the edge of night
Until the stars are all alight.
Then world behind and home ahead
We'll wander back to home and bed.
Mist and twilight
Away shall fade! Away shall fade!
Fire and lamp
And then to bed! And then to bed!
</poem>
=== Frodo's version ===
Another version of this poem is sung by Frodo
column3: as he departs from the Shire with Sam
column4: on their way to the [[Grey Havens]].

column1: <poem style="font-style:italic; margin-left:20px;">
Still round the corner there may wait
A new road or a secret gate
And though I oft have passed them by
A day will come at last when I
Shall take the hidden paths that run
West of the Moon and East of the Sun
</poem>
